stages.description: Tiny oblong seed with fine longitudinal ridges. Slow to wake — patience is the first lesson.
A thin white radicle pushes down into the soil — the very beginning of the taproot. Surface shows nothing yet.
Thread-like cotyledons emerge, easily mistaken for grass. First true leaves show delicate fernlike divisions. Below soil, the taproot is no thicker than a matchstick.
Feathery pinnate foliage fans outward from the crown in a lacy rosette. Underground, the root swells in secret — only the faintest orange shoulder hints at what's forming below.
A bolt — a tall central stalk shoots skyward bearing flat-topped white umbels. Queen Anne's lace in miniature. The root turns woody and fibrous. A loss.
Tiny ridged seeds develop as the umbels dry and curl inward. The root is spent, all its sugar converted to reproductive energy.
Foliage yellows and collapses against the soil. In the ground, the unharvested root slowly softens and returns to earth.

companions.lore: Tomato foliage exudes solanine-scented compounds that mask carrot scent from the carrot rust fly.
Rosemary's intense volatile oils confuse the carrot rust fly, which navigates by smell to find its host.
Shallow-rooted lettuce occupies the top soil layer without competing with the deep carrot taproot, and its leaf canopy shades the soil to retain moisture.
Strawberries' shallow fibrous roots and carrots' deep taproots exploit entirely different soil zones. The strawberry ground cover also helps keep carrot shoulders from greening.

antagonists.lore: Fellow Apiaceae family member — fennel's root exudates inhibit carrot growth, and cross-pollination ruins seed saving for both.

stages.description: Foliage droops slightly in afternoon heat despite adequate water. The damage is underground — larvae tunneling through the root — but the only clue is this subtle wilt.
Outer leaves yellow and redden at the tips. Pull a sacrificial carrot and you'll find rusty-brown tunnels riddling the flesh.
Foliage collapses. The root below is a maze of larval galleries, soft and reeking. Unsalvageable.
Small dark brown spots with yellow halos appear on older outer leaves. Alternaria dauci — the signature blight of carrots.
Spots coalesce and spread inward to younger foliage. Leaf margins curl and blacken. The weakened canopy slows root development below.
Severe defoliation. Most fronds are brown and collapsed. The root survives but will be stunted — less sugar, less size, less flavor.

lore.description: The classic cylindrical carrot — blunt-tipped, sweet-cored, and completely hidden underground until you decide to pull it. Growing carrots is an act of faith.
lore.origin: Nantes, France, 1850s (bred from earlier Dutch orange carrots)
lore.fun_fact: The orange color was likely popularized in the 17th-century Netherlands as a tribute to William of Orange — before that, most carrots were purple, white, or yellow.
